@Colin: I highly doubt magnets in the shoes would work. It is not magnetism, rather than induced current that does the trick. Of course, if they were sufficiently large metallic magnets, they might induce enough of a current, but I doubt they could pedal efficiently (due to the sheer weight) if that were the case.

At the level of GPS, which relies on atomic clocks in orbit, they actually face relativity errors as they are far enough away (so speed of light delays need to be accounted for) and they are moving fast enough (orbital speed) in a gravity field (which affects speed of light) that they are constantly managing them. (Well the US Air Force that is).

Sending MMSes is usually done via the phone's data service - the phone establishes a data session over GPRS, UMTS or CDMA (depending on the host network) and performs a transaction with the network's defined MMS gateway. MMSes are delivered as an XML package with any relevant multimedia (within a defined list of accepted mimetypes) attached to the message and referenced in the XML. Ozeki SMS has lots of technical detail on the specifics of the XML format on its web site [here](http://ozekisms.com/index.php?ow_page_number=459) and [here](http://ozekisms.com/index.php?ow_page_number=458).
@josh "pumping the brakes" is also known as cadence braking and is a commonly used by motorsports drivers whose vehicles do not include ABS (purposely, for a finer degree of control).

This is not correct. They don't say "put your phone in your pocket to get it out of the way." They say "turn it off." A flight attendant never asked me to take a book off my lap in the unlikely event of an emergency. Clearly, it's the *electronics* that are of concern. But whether consumer electronics *actually* cause interference in practice is the subject of study and debate. But that's not the question. The user wants know know what the mechanism is that *reportedly* could cause the interference.

Specifically, ABS rapidly engages and disengages the brakes many times per second in order to reduce a car's velocity in a managed fashion without bringing about total loss of grip - similar to how some cars will 'push back' on the brake pedal when ABS engages, other cars' brake pedals appear to judder/vibrate whilst ABS is engaged - every car differs. On my Dad's Toyota it feels like the brake disengages slightly through the pedal, without the pedal being pushed back towards me, similar to how it feels to slightly depress the clutch pedal on a manual vehicle whilst it's in motion.

Closed as NaRQ, because in its current form this is unanswerable due to lack of specificity (you could probably write an entire economics textbook on the subject, but it wouldn't fit in an answer...) Whether a more specific question (say, "What controls the value of the US dollar?") is on-topic is also in question - if you're interested in asking such a thing, I suggest you bring this up on [Meta](http://meta.htw.stackexchange.com/).

One hopes that modern airplanes are designed with adequately shielded electronics (!), particulary given some airlines are installing onboard picocells for 2G calls. GSM mobiles are particularly prone to emit broadband radiation across various other parts of the RF spectrum, including some that are visible and audible in speaker and display systems. However mobile phones reduce their transmit power if the cell tower is nearby (or SNR is sufficiently high) so the effect is likely to be reduced on an airplane anyway.

Something to consider is the relative accuracy of each: resistive touchscreens are my preferred screen as they are less sensitive to accidental taps and swipes, but they are obviously susceptible to accidental presses by any object. Unfortunately the technology has a limit to its accuracy as a comparatively high amount of pressure needs to be exerted in order to 'activate' the touchscreen. In contrast, capacitive screens are generally far more accurate but are impervious to anything but highly-capacitive objects - I've seen a niche market in "fingertipped" styli and mittens for these devices!
@Locke: Except for the link, your answer doesn't appear to contain an answer at all. It only says what the mechanism **is not**. Can you elaborate a bit?
Blue laser diodes were invented around 1995, CD-ROM were invented in 1978
Something that is called 'roaming' (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roaming)

The reason for the choice of 44.1kHz is due to video! Video devices were originally used to store audio (with binary represented by absolute white / black) given video's superior storage capacity over hard drives of the time. As Henning Schulzrinne (chair of Columbia University's Computer Sciences department) explains, any pseudo-video system (from which CD players are also derived) must use a samplerate based on active lines per frame of video: detail [on Schulzrinne's pages](http://www.cs.columbia.edu/~hgs/audio/44.1.html) and [on Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_rate#Audio).

@Locke - roaming is more a commercial agreement to allow you to use another supplier's service when you are away from home. In the US originally mobile phones were operated by a very local (per town) supplier and wouldn't work outside the local area unless they had a deal with that town's operator
@Robert: you are right, I tried to amend that. Thanks!

Additionally, "16-bit" audio formats such as that used in CD Audio PCM audio allow for representations of amplitude from 00000000 00000000 to 11111111 11111111 and all permutations inbetween; two bytes' worth of data and 65536 amplitude steps to represent the relative -1, 0 and +1 values of an analogue waveform.

The theoretical limit on a suspension bridge is when the cables would break under their own weight - something like 5km for steel cables. The practical limit is making the deck stiff enough to resist twisting in the wind - especially tricky because the whole point of a suspension bridge is that the deck has no strength.

Now, as someone else asked (and I wondered): if you place a bicycle on a perfectly flat treadmill and get it up to speed, should the bike stay in place - at least until it leans and countersteers off the edge of the treadmill? If you had a massive circular treadmill whose direction of movement could be adjusted in both axes, would a bike placed on it be able to keep itself up indefinitely or would the treadmill have to be constantly adjusted depending on the bike's intended direction of movement based on its desire to countersteer?

Well, if the treadmill was flat, you would have to hold the bicycle in place somehow, and that would probably cause you some trouble. On the other hand, if your treadmill was pointing down slightly, then you should be able to get a bicycle to continuously roll on the treadmill, going straight ahead.

laser is shined onto the place; dye absorbs the energy and heat up causing decomposition +/- bubble formation. polycarbonate substrate is heated up causing substrate expansion and fills into the "groove" (where dye originally lives). thus bubbles, bleached dye (due to decomposition), expanded substrate, etc. forms the "groove" necessary for readout

Buffering. In a voice call the problem is latency - the persons voice must get to you in around 10ms or there is no point in having it. Transferring data with TCP isn't time critical - if a packet doesn't get to you because it went to the previous cell -if the cell company don't re-route it the network layer simply requests a new packet. unreliable network links are part of TCP. It's a little trickier with streaming video over UDP

+1 excellent explanation -- just to supplement for those less informed than us: turbofan is kind of a design between turbojet (where combustion causes heating and gaseous expansion to produce propulsion) and turboprop (where most of the energy drives a propeller) - thus part of the gas go into the engine and part of the gas goes around the engine.

AFAIK, the primary purpose of the light *is* to indicate sensor failure, since without the sensors there's no good data for the ABS system to work with! for the don't ask part, in @Pearsonartphoto's answer the S, P, D and F orbitals are from the words sharp, principal, diffuse, fundamental respectively. Those are photographic, morphological description (esp. sharp and diffuse) of spectroscopy film images.

@Jacob it is more of compressing gaseous phase coolant into liquid phase, which causes latent heat (of evaporation) to be released by it onto the fins, and then when it is allowed evaporate, it then is much cooler because the original heat of evaporation was loss to the cooler; particularly, your "then condenses it to cool it" should be written as "it is then allowed to evaporate causing a drop in temperature".

Here in Denver, the pedestrian buttons actually work and does control the state machine driving the lights. One near where I live is miswired and if you wanted to be malicious, you could cause gridlock by repeatedly pressing the button. In this particular case, when a pedestrian wants to cross (the NW <-> NE crossing), it eliminates the left turn arrow from a major N/S street into a shopping center. The left turn traffic will back up and block traffic intending to flow south. By the 3rd light cycle, the traffic in the left most lane will be stopped for a half mile.

@Jacob: Sorry, I got pulled away by a phone call - bubu's right though, while I think your description is correct enough, as far as it goes... It just doesn't feel like it really answers the question. The key to a compressor system is that the compression stage results in a lower volume of gas that *retains its energy*, allowing it to be transfered to the surrounding air as it condenses to a liquid. I think you could improve the way you phrase this to emphasize how the compression allows the gas to transfer heat from a cold medium into a warmer one. Also, TTBOMK R410A is rapidly replacing R22.

To the every day person there are no different kinds of antenna, I think its a valid question. If you can already differentiate between a yagi and a simple dipole, then you probably wouldn't ask the question.

There is but there are two relevant ones. There is a zone of peak power and a zone of peak torque, and they are not necessarily in the same place. (in fact you can be almost sure that they're not). Most performance cars will quote what these are and where they are. Its a little bit more complicated on an electric car because the electronics change it depending on your speed.

Well he says not to copy/paste from there. I simply though why re-explain something that already has a great explanation. By linking it gives credit where it is due.

He says: "I might have to kill it if all we're doing here is posting links to any of the giant other repositories of 'how things work' knowledge on the Internet. When you [just link to a site] well, you just made the Internet a worse place. Why? Because if anyone lands on this page from a Google search, all we've done is delay them on their path to the real answer."

Giving credit where credit is due is **a good thing**. But what you should do is paraphrase their explanation first. (Do **not** copy and paste) and *then* link to their site. What you're doing here is directing the user to their site, I can't get the info I need from your answer alone.

@e.James: there were most definitely ways to limit upshifts with hydraulic systems. You can build logic control circuits with hydraulics instead of transistors if you are so inclined. Instead of electric switches and servos you can use valves. Do google image searches of dashboards for pre-1970s cars and you'll see automatic transmissions with D2, etc. Here is a 1972 AMC hornet, which would have been unlikely to have electronic control, with D2: http://www.justacargeek.com/2011/03/1972-amc-hornet-sportabout.html

Up until recently vector maths was quite hard to do on a microchip. While mathematically its quite easy, try designing a circuit which can take three binary numbers, square them, sum the squares and then find the square root. The square root is especially hard.

Exactly, to test this, write your name with a big fat marker on a piece of paper. Look at it in the mirror and then look at it from the back side of the paper, maybe while holding it up to a light. They should look the same.
It's long and complicated: https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/Pinsetter

@Christopher: race car drivers don't "pump the brakes" while braking, whether they have ABS or not. What they do is "pre-pump" the brakes before entering the braking zone for a corner. This is done to make sure there's enough brake pressure available when entering the braking zone (brake pressure could have been lost due to several reasons in the run up to a corner)

LSD's (limited slip differentials) have little or no relation to TCS. The purpose of LSD is to *lock* the axle between the left and right driven wheels in order to have more traction in (tight) corners. TCS is an electronic system that prevents wheel spin under acceleration in general. In most modern race cars, TCS and LSD are used together (in fact, a race car without LSD is almost undrivable)

In the base of beer, they are often simply bottled in the open air, but after the bottle is filled, the bottle is smacked so that the beer starts foaming. The cap goes on while the foam is flowing out. It does a good job of forcing out all the O2.
